title: For musicians, what was the inspiration to become a musician? - Quora

response.answer_text: Initially, for me music was just for fun only during my high school years and due to some healthy peer pressure from my other musician friends. Although I am not born in a musical family (my family can carry a tune but none of them plays an instrument), my encounter with several singers and musicians back in my school days managed to drag me to the joy of playing music. Determined, I eventually enrolled for some classical guitar and vocal classes back then, learning fundamentals for both instruments. I did not enjoy classical guitar, however, and dropped the instrument altogether for a while, but I continue singing and had fun doing it, and managed to perform repertoire consisting of songs by System Of A Down, Creed, Alter Bridge, and others. It was during my university years, however, when I eventually took music more seriously. I joined a band club in university that consisted of musicians of various levels, ranging from amateurs to professionals and semi-professionals, where I got accepted as a vocalist and at the same time obtained back my passion in guitar. It was also during this time that I discovered the magic of various bands and artists that will become my influences, such as The Beatles, Simon & Garfunkel, Cream, Queen, Elvis Presley, and others. However, although my skills were overall improved, I was not satisfied with my development, especially in singing. I found my voice quite nasal and vocal range limited, and what makes matters worse was that my friends convinced me that my natural range was low although the real issue here is a flawed technique. At the same time, as much as I enjoyed playing guitar, I hit a road block in chording and soloing, realizing that I have been stuck in playing the same patterns over and over.  Eventually, after I graduated from college and began working life, I decided to continue my musical activities in a community choir and also enrolled myself for a new set of guitar lessons in a music school. I really enjoy my choir experience up until this day especially since I manage to get know a literal lot of talented individuals that have possibly sung for their whole lives. My choir conductor is also a very good vocal coach and has successfully managed to expand my vocal range while maintaining a balanced and much more resonant tone. He also fed me with a lot of interval recognition and aural training that has managed to help me tackle more challenging repertoire much more easily. At the same time, my guitar teacher also managed to remove the dead end within my improvement by encouraging me to learn various chord voicings to make the music that I am playing a lot more interesting. From then on, I certainly know that I am on the right track, especially since I feel a lot happier playing music for my families, friends and loved ones, as well as knowing a lot of extremely talented and experienced musicians who are humble in sharing their knowledge to me. Overall, the journey has been extremely fun, and full of ups and downs, yet I feel much more alive than ever. The reasons that I have played music in the first place, i.e. to be able to feel that joy and share it to others around me, are still the same from my teenage days.

I was surrounded by music of varying genres at a young age. I began singing in church choir but when I was given the opportunity to learn an instrument in fifth grade, I took it because I wanted to learn a different side to music. I was then accepted into a performing arts middle school which gave me the opportunity to learn more about music, so I decided to take piano classes. (I would have started on piano if that had been an option in fifth grade.) Around this time I started coming up with little melodies but my school didn't have classes to take for composition. At my performing arts high school I was required to take theory and I enjoyed every minute of it. One day during the dinner break of a Saturday rehearsal, I was playing my rendition of Carol of the Bells, may I note that I hadn't began playing my real compositional part, and a "friend" told me it sucked. I had just listened to him play his renditions, that I didn't necessarily like, of several pop songs for about half an hour until he left to use the restroom. After he told me that my music sucked, I let him know my feelings towards his covers and he threw a temper tantrum. We were never friends again, but after that incident was when I first realized that composition was something I had a deep passion for. I then used a music notation software for the first time ever and thought that if I could compose music for the rest of my life that my life would be complete. I am now majoring in music composition at Loyola University New Orleans and there are quite a few people who believe that my music doesn't suck but that my music is pretty neat!

I'm not sure if this question is solely limited to professional musicians, but if it is, feel free to downvote. I'm a musician. I don't make a living at it like most of the responders do here, but I'm a musician all the same. I do perform with local theater companies and in my church as a solo performer.  I cannot remember a time when I wasn't doing something music related-I started piano instruction at age five. I learned to read music at the same time I learned to read.  My father was a classical pianist, and we had music in the family every day I can remember.  My dad would tell me that when I was a baby, he'd play a certain Chopin waltz, and it would make me cry. Don't know why, but I knew enough to know that THAT particular combination of sounds needed to be reacted to every time. As a child and a teen, I identified as a musician. My father was my primary teacher. Being a pianist was simply a part of what I was. Later on, as an adult, I started singing becuase I wanted more opportunities to engage in music. I wanted to be a professional, but I didn't have the confidence to think that I could actually make a living at it, so I studied engineering. I don't regret it. In fact, pursuing an alternative profession that pays well allows me to have the resources to pursue serious study. I currently take voice lessons with a private teacher, something that would be difficult to do if I didn't have a steady job that pays well.  I also don't have to worry about scrounging work to pay the rent-I have the luxury of choosing those productions/shows that I want to do, not taking opportunities that don't do anything for me. And dedication? Heh. YOU try going to work for eight-nine hours a day, and then going to rehearsal for a show for an additional 2-3 hours or more. AND finding time to practice/learn your music or dialogue on your own as well. Every show I do, there is at least one week where we rehearse until near midnight every day of that week before it launches, and I still have get up in the morning and go to work. And in many cases, we don't get paid for it, or when we do get a stipend, it covers maybe a tank of gas. We nonprofessionals have dedication up the wazoo. We do it for one reason-we love it.

For me, its all I ever wanted to do. When I was five years old, I had this book I used to write in. When my mom asked what I wanted to do when I got older, I always said, “I am going to be a drummer when I’m older” not “I want to be a drummer”. There was nothing that came along between the ages of five and until my mom passed away when I was 16 that I wanted to do more than play the drums. On her deathbed, my mom told me to play the drums. So, my future was mapped out for me. I remember being in High School, meeting with counselors asking me what I was going to do for college. I told them, “1. My dad doesn’t have the money to pay for college, 2. I don’t want to go to college and 3. I’m going to play the drums.” The counselors would tell me it wasn’t an option, but I told them it was the only option I had. I didn’t have any other options. It was do or die for me. My pops would always tell me to have plan-b and plan b was an escape plan. I started getting tattoos and what I called “job stoppers” everywhere. I wanted tattoos and I knew it would prevent me from getting a normal job. I positioned myself with my back against the wall so I had no other choice than to do what I absolutely loved. I think sometimes you have to do that. If you love playing the guitar, you love rapping or you love producing music, you have to do it. That’s it. Don’t worry about driving a nice car, having nice clothes, or a nice place to live. Just concentrate on doing what you love and the good stuff will come.

I think my interest in music started when I was 7 years old. There was a popular cartoon that appeared at TV every day for several months, and I was watching it as I was a child. The background soundtrack was entirely classical music. I was born with synesthesia (an ”exaggerate” connexion between different senses which allowed me to see surreal, epic worlds when I listened to music) so I started to wonder: ”How can music do that! This is truly outstanding!”. I would start composing music earlier, but I had no relative interested in music and as I used to keep many interests just for myself nobody noticed that I discovered something extraordinaty in music. When I was 11, I accidentally discovered a music software, a DAW: FL Studio, which is very well-known. I was good at computers and I learned to use them by myself in several months (this including more sophisticated things, such as Registry Editor, hidden settings, even creating harmful viruses!) so using a computer software for composing music became just natural for me. I was fascinated by FL Studio. I still remember my first piece, the summer I composed it... But the school began and I had a lot of work. I had no anymore time to discover the program. As usual, nobody noticed I like music, because I showed almost nobody what I am doing with the software. Everybody around me started to listen to awful contemporary hits, which used to give me serious headaches and made me feel very sick (my synesthesia showed me nothing for these songs, just a void dark space). I somehow managed to compose something a bit classical (the genre I liked then), and I was so fascinated about it that I told myself that I must continue (it was not a very complex song, but it was the best I have composed at that time). I unfortunately gave up on FL Studio when the ”real” schoolwork came and I had to participate to contests, Olympiads, to work on class projects and so on, but at the end of the sixth grade, I started writing books, and I was always imagining that there were movies based on them, so someone had to compose soundtracks for them. It soon began too hard to explain everything I was feeling by writing, so I had to find a new, more expressive way - again, I had to compose music. When I was 13, I started using FL Studio again (my synesthesia evolved a lot and allowed me even to ”live” in the worlds the music created for me, to feel the moods in there) and I also discovered some useful plugins and sound libraries to help me compose (the software has some in-built plugins and electronic sounds, but their quality is not really the best). At 14 years old, I started using it intensively, and I managed to create some of my best electronic tracks. This summer, at 15 years old, I almost completely changed my stile and started treating the DAW as a ”professionist” (I started using the mastering utilities, the hidden sound editors and so on). I even got a soundtrack request for a small project. During all this time, I never knew any music theory at all! And, most important, I never gave up on originality and I am still against the generic, common sound patterns we can hear everywhere around and tell almost nothing. I am still listening to classical music and I deeply respect it as my first journey to the wonderful, complex world of music. If you are interested, here is my YT channel: Julia Saltflower Thank you for your patience to read all of this :)

I think I had a feeling I would go into music all my life. When I was little, I wanted instruments, and wanted to be a rockstar, and a bluegrass fiddler, and “Janis-Joplin-if-she-were-a-nine-year-old-boy-and-also-not-dead” (Nine year old me had high hopes for us) My great-uncle bought me a harmonica at age six, and I still have it, and play it (well, I play my newer harps more- that one was run over by a truck a few times and it’s a miracle it still plays decently. Not pushing my luck) I stumbled across a notation editor back in high school that changed my life, though. Myriad Music Maker. I think I tripped past it looking up the Vocaloid software, after an online friend introduced me to that whole can of worms. Up until that point, I knew I enjoyed music, but I didn’t think I could make music. I still have my first compositions, saved on my old desktop back home. I may have even uploaded them somewhere, I can’t remember. They were chaotic and quirky, and lack all conceived notions of western tonal harmony- I was just bashing away at my computer keyboard until cool things happened. I didn’t even know what scales were, or what that funky 4 on top of another 4 meant. But I kept at it, and later came upon Finale 2010, then Finale 2012, then Finale 2014, and before my laptop keeled over and died, I’d upgraded to the latest version, Finale 25. I have a big portfolio of compositions now. But none of that would have happened, beyond those first four pieces, had I not been friends with a percussionist and a bass clarinetist in my high school’s band. They wanted me to join band so they could hang out with me more, and also because the band was getting smaller and needed more people. I said maybe, if I had time. They offered me three tangerines- one from each of them, and the bass clarinetist grabbed an extra from someone who didn’t have a need for citrusy bribery. I decided, with further introspection and a growling stomach, that I did, in fact, have time. The rest was history. I joined band, got slapped onto drumline, considering my considerable lack of experience playing any other band instrument (I was informed in short order that harmonica and Guitar Hero guitar were not appropriate band instruments.) I got a glockenspiel for my sixteenth birthday, joined the jazz band when my first band director left, and the new one started teaching jazz, playing harmonica. I only had a C harp, though- eventually, I got a Bb too, but after a few weeks, my band director suggested maybe I try playing xylophone. I was reluctant at first, because I had no idea how to improvise on xylophone- harmonica, I had learned by ear, improvising was easy (and wowed the judges at Elon Jazz Festival- they definitely didn’t expect a harmonica solo on “Chameleon.”) But, I gave it a try, and fell in love. Later that year, he let me try out some marimba mallets he had, and I found a set that sounded great on our old clunky xylo. I started using those in jazz band, and it sounded a lot better. I fell head over heels for the vibraphone when I first laid eyes on one in person, on stage at Elon Jazz Festival- students were using the other two, so I didn’t get to warm-up or rehearse on it before we went on, so it was my very first time playing. Lot of fun. That spring, I was selected to apply for NC Governor’s School, and the moment of truth came- I could either audition for the Music program, or send in a portfolio for the Art program (at the time, I was debating between majoring in Music or Visual Arts, in college.) I ended up going with music, and proceeded to absolutely bomb my audition. I had no idea how to play timpani, and the best I could do on snare drum was haphazardly improvise what sounded like a marching cadence. I also brought a two-mallet solo (Gossec’s “Gavotte”) for marimba, an instrument I’d only played twice before (I had to go to Oxford, NC for lessons at a guy’s house. My school didn’t have one.) The guy conducting the audition liked my choice of music, because he liked the Looney Tunes. He did not like the fact that I had memorized the piece, but only as a whole, and definitely not the measure numbers. He also didn’t care for the fact that I only brought one copy of the score, and when he asked for specific measure numbers, I had to walk over to him and check, over his shoulder. It was a good learning experience, though! My teacher brought his vibes all the way from Michigan, my senior year. I claimed them as my own, and only I, and my designated protégée, were allowed to play them. Nobody contested that, because I was the only senior percussionist, and also the only one who knew how to play keyboard instruments at all. I ended up teaching everyone else, but the vibes were mine. I auditioned that year for Brevard College, and learned from my first audition- I brought in four solo pieces and an improvisation on “Bag’s Groove,” for vibes. I was only supposed to bring in something for snare, and something for marimba. Nailed it. Once there, I took the Music Education path, which was a good decision because at the end of my sophomore year, they dropped their Music Performance degree (to all of the Music Performance majors’ vast outrage.) Also a good decision because my high school band director showed me that I wanted to teach music. And now I’m here. Giving a senior recital next spring, just played a junior recital this past spring. Pieces I’ve composed and arranged have been played in front of an audience. A musician’s journey. My life.

My father was a successful musical theater composer, which was pretty much the start of everything. It's the reason there was a piano in my house, and the reason I thought of "musician" as something you could do and still be a respectable human being. For most of my friends, the choice to become a musician was in some sense an act of rebellion that it wasn't for me. My dad told me a few months ago that "if you'd wanted to be a doctor or a lawyer I would have been fine with it, but deep down I would have been a little disappointed." Around the time I could walk, I started playing the piano for fun. I wasn't taking lessons yet, but I'd climb up on the bench, and I figured out how to make major chords, and play them in parallel. I got piano lessons, I played for a while, and then started composing. I didn't want my dad to know about the composing and give me a hard time, so I did it mostly in secret, but by the time I was graduating from high school I had shown him some of my stuff, made recordings, etc. I went to college hoping to double-major in music and math, because math was what I did well in school, and music was what I did well out of school. In my first couple years of college, I took some pretty hard/time-consuming math, and enjoyed it, but I just remember this irrepressible feeling that it was taking time away from my real life. Music never felt like that, for me. I'd pull an all-nighter working on music and the next morning I'd crave sleep; I'd pull an all-nighter working on math and the next morning I'd crave vacation. This isn't a good reason to become a musician. Nor is the ever-popular "I couldn't do anything else" (if you really have no other skills/interests, you're probably a pretty terrible musician). In my case , there were two moments of inspiration to become a musician: the first is the one mentioned above, when I started hanging out at the piano as a little kid. This moment gets a lot of credit from a lot of musicians, but it doesn't seem like the real one to me. For me, there was a second moment that came mid-way through college. I was taking this music class with a famous musicologist, and we needed to memorize pieces for a needle-drop test. One of the pieces on the list was Wotan's Farewell, from the end of Wagner's "Die Walküre." My dad had hated Wagner because of the antisemitism, so I'd never heard it before, and I needed to listen over and over again, so I could get this music through my thick skull.   George London singing it, basically rocking out. The music was absolutely astonishing to me, and I remember thinking that I would be willing to work harder than any other person on earth to be able to make these sounds. Being a musician is hard, and if you're not willing to do more for it than for anything else, you haven't yet been inspired to become a professional musician. At that point, I'd been saying I wanted to become a musician for a couple decades, but that was the moment I actually decided to work hard enough to ensure that it'd happen.

I have a hard time calling it “inspiration.” In some ways what led me to music was, and still is, a bit of a curse. A wonderful, maddening curse. There is always music in my head. Always. Sometimes it is something I heard recently, sometimes it is something I have never heard before. It has been that way since I can remember. Sometimes I even dream something that has been stuck in my head all day. This is what I refer to as part A of the curse. The worst is when it’s a song that you know that you know, but you can’t figure out what it is. I’ve had that going on for the last three days now. I don’t think I heard it anywhere, since it’s an old and somewhat obscure song. It seems to have just showed up out of the blue. I know this song, and I’m pretty sure I used to own the record. But what is it? Who is the artist? What is the title? It’s instrumental, so there are no lyrics to search to try to figure it out. It is driving me positively crazy!! So that is part A of the curse — the constant music in my head. Part B of the curse is that, for me, there’s really no such thing as “background music.” If what is going on outside my head is drowning out what is going on inside my head, I’m still not at peace because it is virtually impossible for me to hear music without analyzing it. What instruments are involved in this piece? What is the time signature. That’s an interesting drum beat — just what is that drummer doing there? I can’t quite resolve that odd chord progression, what the heck is that? Then there is the double-whammy, which has been happening the last few days with that song that is stuck in my head. Not only can I not figure out what it is, I cannot stop analyzing it either!! It is extremely distracting. My wife keeps asking me, “What’s wrong?” or, “What are you thinking about?”, or simply, “Where are you?” I try to explain that there’s a song in my head and I’m trying to figure it out. She says, “Oh I know. I hear Christmas music everywhere.” No, dear, you don’t know. You remember Christmas music that you heard somewhere. This is different. So back to “inspiration.” I was not inspired to become a musician, I was driven to it. I had to pick up a guitar and learn to play it so I could try to share with others the stuff that was inside my head that didn’t originate from outside my head!! Ironically, to learn the guitar I practiced by playing along to stuff from outside my head so I could figure out how to play the stuff that was inside my head that didn’t originate from outside my head. Confused yet? Imagine me back then!! I hear things so precisely in my head that I learned to play everything by ear. I learned to read music so that I could talk about it properly with other people, but I have never learned a song from sheet music or tab. Everything is by ear. Once in a while if I think that a fingering that I am using is particularly awkward I will look at the tab to see if there’s something else I could do, but about half of the time I end up rejecting it because it doesn’t sound quite right to me. Oh, BTW, in case anyone is unaware, when you have a song stuck in your head and you can’t get it out, do you know what that is called? It’s called an earworm. Honest. Look it up! I guess I have chronic earworm syndrome. (O_o)

It's not like we musicians suddenly get inspired by a movie and grab a guitar or something. We are born with the talent and it wants to get out, it's like an instinct we cannot control. Even if we didn't have our instruments, we would do finger drumming to any song, fantasize detailed guitar solo's in our head even on the crappiest pop song and enjoy singing along anything singable. It's something that we are born with, not something attained later. I started playing the piano when I was 9, and I started because I wanted to start not because my parents wanted or something. I grew up listening to Ray Charles and Blues Brother's, and I was absolutely amazed by the joy and energy of their music. Unlike other kids who enjoyed playing outside, I would sit and listen to blues albums for hours, with closed eyes, and would imagine the scene. My parents were no musicians, I didn't have any role model to be inspired from. It's just that I enjoyed listening to music much more than playing ball outside in the dirt or riding bicycles or climbing trees or lego's or whatever. Nothing amused me more than that. And when I found an old toy keyboard in the cellar, it immediately became my favorite toy. I even composed something and showed it to my father. He was very excited, so I started taking piano lessons. Soon, I would spend hours playing piano everyday, improvise, discover, try everything I can after or before I finished my classical piano exercises. After 2 years, I performed a classical piano song on the school's end-of-the-year talent show where kids of my age (11) would perform their talents in front of their teachers and parents, and that was the irreversible moment in my life when my talent was publicly noticed and my self confidence was boosted more than ever. Just 2 years after that, I sang my first song as a lead singer, and was very well received. In high school I was even more appreciated and won many prizes in musical competitions and performed in many places with my band. And in college, I performed over 200 gigs with a professional band and even released an album, started composing full-band rock songs, recording, editing, mixing, mastering, writing lyrics, jingles, and much more. So basically most musicians don't get inspired by anything. They are born with the talent, and when they get in touch with music even in the simplest form of "listening", their talent gets triggered to burst out. And only once after they are appreciated, it becomes an irreversible passion for life-time.

I think I decided to become a musician when I heard our family friend, Stacy Orico, on the radio. I remember being in my dad’s baby blue Buick Lasaber, driving on the freeway in our little country town and her song came on the radio…all the way out there. She was only fourteen at the. The second I heard her I was like, “whoa-whoa-whoa-what-what?!” We only get about six radio stations out there so it was a huge deal so when that happened, something clicked in my head and I knew I wanted to do something great. If my friend, who was as human as I was, could do it and figure out a way to travel the world and sing her songs, then I could too. Maybe it was foolish pride at play, but when you’re a kid you think anything is possible.  At that point in my life, I had a real passion for music and I loved singing. I had always done music with my family and started kind of writing songs and singing songs at social gatherings just to get attention. Truth is, I’ve been an attention whore my entire life. I would perform Green Day songs in front of my classmates to get girls’ attention, but then I realized there was something much bigger that I could do.  Because my parents didn’t raise me listening to soul and r&b, I did my research. A friend introduced me to Stevie Wonder’s music and something happened inside me where I knew I had found the music I was going to make. It made me melt and it continues to make me feel alive when I listen to it. That’s not to say I don’t like other genres of music, I love a lot of different types, but there was just something about soul and r&b. I can’t explain it fully. A few months later, I was introduced to Stevie Wonder, Donny Hathaway and Aretha Franklin and it was all down hill from there. I was sold.

I'd say there's some genetic aspect to it, as my father was musically inclined, so I naturally picked up guitar playing from him. He would play and sing his old time country music but I was too cool for that, growing up in the sixties. So, I held an interest in playing guitar but not singing, too shy I guess, from an early age and somewhere along the line in my youth I got a guitar of my own, which was about the only thing my father and I seemed to have in common. Long story short, I ended up being a better guitarist than him but really too shy to do anything serious with it. I had some professional musical ambitions but would have needed to meet the right people to truly follow that path. I met some interesting musical people, but not the right ones. The genetic component to musicality doesn't of course tell the whole story. What's going on inside, what's the inspiration? I have, at least from the time I was about ten as I remember, always loved what struck me as good music and I wasn't really caught in any particular category. Could've been anything that caught my ear. What really jump started my lifelong musical affection was, like so many others of my time, The Beatles. I have vivid memories of their first appearance in America on the Ed Sullivan tv show and like many kids back then the experience of that phenomenon and all of the Beatlemania to follow left its indelible impression on me and probably left me somewhat useless for other interests. I was hooked, but only took music amatuerly seriously, as I had girls and school and other growing up pressures to deal with. Looking back I know I could only have gone more serious with music if I'd had a suitable cohort for such an off the beaten path life adventure. Still, as a listener and lifetime music connoisseur, I can say that something about the experience of what I consider to be the best of musical offerings has definitely illuminated my inner world and I truly believe helped me to be a better person for it. For me, and I suspect most other serious music listeners, the highest musical expressions have a truly transcendent quality to them that can take the respective listener to mental planes that might be otherwise inaccessible. What I consider ‘good' music will definitely exercise one's imagination and all this is the key I think to why anyone would be inspired to play other people's music and even create their own unique musical landscapes.

Lots of good answers here. I've been involved in making music since I was 5 years old. I've been playing guitar for 45 years. For me there were so many reasons. The Beatles were exploding during my young years and I ate that stuff up. At a very young age someone gave me a big hardbound book with The Songs of Lennon and McCartney. That was it for me. Of course there's the whole "to get girls" angle but that has more to do with why I decided to perform music. Deep down I don't perform music for other people. I play it because it's inside me and it needs to come out. It's like meditation and therapy for me. Sometimes I play soft and melodic. Sometimes I play loud and angry. Sometimes I play well, sometimes badly. Music is the one constant in my life. Everything else changes. Music persists. Here we are in 2015 (almost) and I still listen to The Beatles along with everything from Mozart to Charli XCX. Then I pick up my Tele.

Music is a really demanding career and you have to be really motivated and disciplined to be able to succeed at it-- and even then, there are no guarantees. Given that, really the only reason to do it is if you can't stand *not* doing it. Growing up, I had a lot of hobbies and academic interests, and I still do; but one year I went the whole summer without singing or practicing piano, and honestly got kind of depressed. When I picked them back up again in the fall, it was really cathartic and I realized how important music was to my emotional health. I just really need that meditative state that the deep focus of a practice session gives, in order to stay sane. I don't think musicians are necessarily "inspired" to make a go at being a professional-- it's a serious decision like any other career would be. I could have kept music as a hobby and done something else instead, but the right doors opened at the right time, and I ended up doing music.

Inspiration? Didn’t need no inspiration! Music grabbed me and wouldn’t let go and then I wasn’t really able to do anything else so there it is! My parents were both visual artists who were also good at music in their own way, so there was always music around even when I was a baby. As a child I told my dad I was going to be a composer. At school my singing brought the other kids to tears. I saw a movie once where a beautiful lady calmed an entire crowd that was about to riot, by just singing and then asking them to let her sleep in peace. That really stayed with me, even though I don’t remember the rest of the movie at all. So I always knew. But when I was about 12 I thought music wouldn’t be practical for making a living, and my voice dropped to mezzo which was a huge disappointment to me, so I considered several other careers. I did an initial study of a few different things that looked interesting but nothing except music held my interest for longer than 3 months. At 13 I dedicated to music. It’s been a weird road, but I am and always will be a musician.

Started as a guitar player, I thought it would be so cool to play in a band as a guitar player. Making solos and going crazy on stage, I loved the image of that. The crowd cheering while you play it and the adrenaline going into you and it becomes intense. I played guitar for a couple of years but soon became bored of it because I didn't think it was fun, I didn't like that fact the guitarist just stood on stage and moved their finger only. I soon became interested in bass, I saw one of my favorite bands bass player and he was just moving to the rhythm and I loved it! I thought the bass player felt the music a lot more than the guitarist (not true I know). I wanted to become a bass player and I knew I could because it isn't a whole lot different than the guitar, but I did soon realize it took more strength in the fingers. This didn't bother me but it did, I have long fingers and honestly ugly crooked ones. I just couldn't press my fingers in a whole lot to make the sounds I wanted to but it soon got easier, although I kept getting better I realized that I still didn't like doing this, I wasn't as interested as I am today. I found it way to complicated for my head and wasn't as much fun as drumming. Yes I became a drummer and for the first time in my life I have found out what I want to do for the rest of my life and that is drumming. My guitar teacher was the one who got me into drumming in the first place ironically. He pushed me to be better and I ended becoming really good after 7 months. I had realized that drumming interests me so much, I love the various amounts of cymbal sounds, the options you have of drums and how to form your kit and the different styles you can play for different genres. My inspiration was Tomas Haake, I though the polyrhythms were crazy and I though that they sounded perfect, soon Danny Carey became my inpiration. After I found Danny Carey I saw how much creativity goes into music and how much effort it takes to make something sound good like that. Point is, being creative is a big inpiration, making your own unique sounds and beats to a song and reaching mastery level. Comparing a beginner drummer to an expert one pleasures me.

For me, I have been surrounded by music my whole life. I always played Guitar Hero with my brother and my dad, my mom is.. Kinda the "lead singer" in her church choir, my dad LIKES playing the drums (but really, he can't xD), my brother shreds the guitar, and my dad would play and / or talk about music non-stop. That last one is the strongest. It really depends on the person, but I think people really need to be pulled into what they're listening to. If they aspire to be a guitar player, then while listening to songs, they feel something once they here it. Same with bass players, drummers, singers, and so on. When you truly feel that amazing, bizzare feeling in your chest and stomach when listening to your favorite song, possibly balling your eyes out (totally me every day XD), then you're inspired and in love. I want to be where 5FDP and KoRn are, and I'm not nearly 1/100 as good as my brother. And he isn't nearly 1/100 as good as them. Well.. Probably..  But guess what? Music is inspiring me to keep going.  ..SO YEAH.

My dad was an audiophile and every Sunday, back in the 60’s, he would turn on his stereo equipment and played all kinds of music; Classical, Soundtracks, Big Band, Jazz, Popular Latin American music, etc. I was just 5 years old back then but, I still remember vividly that whenever my father played the Theme from Exodus soundtrack, I would run outside and looked at the sky while I heard the music. It was so grand and magnanimous that seeing the immense blue skies was the only equivalent to listening to that masterpiece. Soon I realized music was a trigger to my sensibility, that I naturally understood music theory (not writing or reading music, but the math in music, the relationship between notes, the significance of intervals, time, etc). And music became my world since then. At 9 fell in love with the drums, and my father bought me a semi-pro drum set (not a toy at all). At 11 I started to learn bass. At 15 I was already an accomplished drummer and bassist playing gigs here and there (hiding my age). By then I also started learning the guitar, first in an acoustic guitar, then switched to the electric guitar, then a Puerto Rican instrument called the cuatro. After that I expanded my percussion instruments to include timbales, congas, bongos, clave, guiros, the works. Soon came the piano, flute, and saxophone. As with percussion, I expanded my interest in strings by learning how to play the tiple, bordonua, ukulele, mandolin, bandurria and other instruments. As you can see, learning a new instrument was just a new challenge I enjoyed.

Music is my language. I am a professional musician now, maybe I won't be in the future, but I'll always be a musician. I'm not sure there was a time that I "became" a musician. In fact, I never thought of myself as a musician until recently. But I always was. Some people are comfortable with money. Others express themselves with visual images. Music has always been what is at my core. I used to sing, all the time. People would ask me why I'm so happy. What a strange question! Singing has nothing to do with being happy, or sad. It is simply my language.  Inspiration? I didn't have any inspiration to become a musician. There have been moments when music has revealed great beauty to me, unlocked sadness, enabled me to feel the warmth of connection and the depth of loneliness. Yet, there was never any point when I could have said "that's what I want to be" or "that's not me."

I was blessed with a musical family on my mother's side. I used to drive my mom crazy playing on her pots and pans and she was going crazy! My cousin then brought me to a music store (at the age of 5), and bought me my first drum. By 7 years old I was already a professional musician performing with bands. Another blessing I got was the middle and high schools I attended. Both of them were musical and academic at the same time. In the mornings we had the normal classes such as math, reading, etc. but in the afternoons from 1-6 pm we had Harmony, ear training, applied piano, applied instrument, band, solfege, forms and analysis, theory and counterpoint. By the time I graduated from high school we graduated with two diplomas, one in general education and the other one in music. I've been in music since then and continue today as a band leader, arranger, composer, vocalist and percussionist of my on Salsa band in San Diego. I've produced 2 cds, and I am currently working on 2 more productions, on on a Bomba y Plena cd dedicated to my uncle and a Salsa CD dedicated to my father. About my style of music? Because I traveled pretty much around the world with the US Navy Band, my music is a fusion of Classical, Salsa, Merengue, Afro-Cuban/Caribbean and Jazz.  I see myself performing until I am 99 years old and loving every minute of it!

After graduating from Cal, I finally strayed from my cautious ways after bumping into my human hinge of fate John Perona one night in the aftermath of a 1968 Telegraph Avenue riot. John was an acid head who wandered the halls of our dorm talking to himself. I can see him now, staring eerily at me through wisps of tear gas. “Arnie,” he mumbled, “they need a sax at the Lucky 13.” I checked it out. It was a soul club a couple of miles from Cal and light-years away culturally. Whites, blacks and Latinos dancing to Otis Redding, Sam and Dave, Booker T and the MGs. The war, racial disharmony, intellectual discussions of capitalism were nowhere to be seen. I sat in on tenor and got my first gig. My new boss was Satan. Wait. Make that Lord Luther McDaniels, living off the faded glory of his hit, “White Port And Lemon Juice.” My band-mates were Rudy Fuentes and Beto Zendejas, a Cisco Kid/Pancho pair: Beto austerely chording on guitar and singing “I’m So Proud,” Rudy stabbing cheerily at his Hammond organ, a rotund, garrulous stereotype. Rudy is the only musician I’ve known who arrived late for a gig claiming his two rear tires blew simultaneously. Another little Latino guy at the Lucky 13 offered me my first free sample of “Sometheeng to wake you up, main!” …and then came the stash of little yellow cigarettes I kept under the ashtray of my English Ford…. (from my memoirs, soon to be a major Hollywood movie starring Michael Cohen and Rachel Maddow.)

I'll try not to tell my life story, but I started playing the accordion 54 years ago, played in a bar for money when I was seven, and had fake ID to get where I played when I was a teenager, the accordion had changed to an electric keyboard and gutar. I think I've always been a musician.  When I was five, my parents had two odd grownups come over and test me to see if I could play music, which was absurd. They stretched my fingers out and measured, had me raise different fingers; I didn't know what they were looking for, but I sure didn't have big hands or any particular coordination. They were from the music store, looking for customers. I went through all sorts of music lessons on accordion, piano, and guitar and one year I got a new teacher. He was a "semi-retired" jazz sax player. He taught me how to improvise and it was those first few solos I took that told me I was a musician. We would play jazz standards and "trade eights." When I wanted to play Beatle songs, he let me. By then I was playing with my friends who had guitars and eventually a band was formed and it just went from there. I have never regretted anything I skipped out on over music. I'll thank the memory of that sax man forever.

I was just born a musician, I didn't have to become inspired. Like a fish can swim. Perfect pitch, ability to play a song right now that I heard when I was ten, never seeing the music, have not heard it since that time, never played it back in the day. If you mean become a professional musician, I weighed a few choices: Chemist, Accountant or Musician. Musician won. Not by inspiration, by pure desire to do something that fit my nature better, based on a logical choice that it was more ‘inevitable’ than the other choices. I have been INSPIRED by great musicians. Leonard Bernstein, Claude Debussy, Janis Joplin, Paul McCartney, Art Tatum, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck, Antonio Carlos Jobim, etc.

I didn't care about music at all before college.  I took a couple violin lessons, I think, in junior high, but I hated it and my parents didn't force it on me.  I listened to popular music in the 80s, but didn't collect anything, really. But in college I took a required Humanities course with a music history portion and, wow... Suddenly I couldn't get enough of the stuff.  I was buying every album I could get my hands on, studying music history... I was insatiable. But it didn't translate to wanting to play music.  I had been writing song lyrics, but more as a side effect of trying to be a writer in general-- I didn't think songwriting was something to focus on.   One Christmas I was broke, so I got a couple friends together to record a Capella X-mas tunes to send out as gifts.  Afterward we decided to take a crack at writing and recording songs together, and they came out better than any of us would've expected.   We then went our separate ways-- one guy became a doctor, another guy became an administrator for Doctors Without Borders... And I decided to pursue being a musician.  What else could I do?

For musicians, what was the inspiration to become a musician? I was inspired to play guitar when I was around 12 years old, but didn’t actually pick one up until I was 14. My parents were too poor to buy me one. My inspiration for wanting to play/create music was my brother. He wasn’t a musician, but I remember him playing his 8 track (yes, I’m getting old) of AC/DC. The sound of the guitars had me “Thunderstruck”, if you will. I finally got a used guitar when I was 14 from a friend. It had only the 1st and 2nd strings on it. Believe it or not I actually started to learn melodies with only those two strings. I was very inspired to be a musician when I first heard Claude Debussy’s songs, “Claire De Lune” and “The Girl with the Flaxen Hair”. I’m not sure why, but Debussy’s music hit a nerve in me. I wanted to be able to capture human emotion in my music like Debussy. I’m no professional musician. I have created a few songs that have been recorded. I never really set out to become a professional musician. Music was more of an escape for me, growing up in a very volatile home I needed a way to deal with it all. Music really did save my life. Instead of going out with my buddies and getting in trouble, I elected to stay home and play guitar.

Several factors. My mother wanted me to play piano, so I took lessons from age 7 to age 15. I hated it and never really got good, but took those lessons I did. My mother (again) always had music on at home and she LOVED to swing. This is the 1960s I’m talking about, so as a small boy I heard *ALL* of Ella’s catalog. I’d dance with her, talk about the music - she loved to swing and dance. So did I, but more importantly, it created a sense of groove in me that I’ve found VERY FEW folks around me have. Not bragging here - I’m lucky and I’m cursed - most folks can’t hear the difference, but a drummer who can’t swing drives me *nuts*! Finally, I’d say the whole “music culture” of the ‘70s. As a teen, what we had to kill time was our stereo. So we collected records, compared artists and tunes - it became an obsession to many of my peers - and then one day, we said “let’s form a band” - and I’ve been gigging ever since. That was 40 freakin’ years ago… yikes!

When I was 9 years old, I was the tallest kid in my class. One day, we all went to the auditorium and were introduced to the instruments of the Orchestra. I saw the bass, and I felt like we had something in common...it was tall like me! A few years later, I got a bass guitar for christmas. Two friends had guitars and another had drums. We started a band, and once covered a Metallica song for the pizza guy. I was only really into rock and roll (for listening), but I played every chance I could. I was in the Orchestra, Jazz Band, the previously-mentioned rock band, Concert Band (trombone), and Choir.  When I was 16, our High School Jazz Band was touring the elementary schools to get kids interested in music. We played, the Percussion Ensemble played, and at my old elementary school, a cellist (who was the other student in my lessons as that tall 9-year-old) performed a solo.  As I said, until this point, I was only really interested in rock music, but during her solo, something "clicked." That's the only way I can describe it. It was a change that happened inside me in a split second, and I thought to myself - "This is what I want to do for the rest of my life."

I had wanted to be a pianist for a long time, but when i was 14, something happened that I cannot explain. I was sitting on my bed with my computer listening to a piece of piano music, it wasn’t amazing but it was a decent piece I had heard before. I closed my eyes and let the music fill me, and then I had an epiphany. I started crying uncontrollably and the only thing I felt was the overwhelming feeling that i had to be a musician. That I would do anything to make music my life. And this wasn’t just me being inspired by a nice piece of music. I felt as if if was my only purpose, something that i absolutely had to do. To this day, I have never felt such an intense emotion in my life. It probably wasn’t what made me become a musician, but it definitely was significant.

More or less my dad guilted me into joining the high school marching band. Opportunities that he never had as a kid, yadda, yadda. Not only did I excel in learning multiple instruments, it became a path for me to not be the awkward outside looking in kid through high school. Sophomore year someone handed me a Bass guitar 20 mins before an audition and after that I was hooked. Played in different bands for the next 20 plus years, several with different milestones of success. Semi-Retired now raising a family and working for the man but I wouldn't change any of the memories I have for anything. Also I'd like to note that music is my full-time passion. Music is on constantly everywhere I'm at and any free time I have I read, play or think about it. I still define myself as a musician to this day.

I can't control being a music-person any more than I can control having brown hair or being left-handed.  I did, eventually, make a concious decision to become a professional musician after I had tried a few other careers and realized that they weren't for me. The feeling of waiting for the work day to be over so I could get back to being myself was almost unbearable. I might as well have been in prison for eight hours each day. I also felt I was betraying the good people I was working with; people who liked the job and wanted to do it well. It felt rude to be there. Moments of action upon true inspiration are rarely profound, or even enjoyable. Usually, it's just a case of, "Well, fuck it." (Pardon the profanity, but those are the only words that have ever occurred to me when confronted by destiny.)

Angus Young and his brother Malcolm. I was into sone disco type music, along with stuff like the sex pistols(i know weird combo but with my dad listening to led zepplin, Santana and the beetles, my best friends older brother listened to dance music at the time along with eagles steely dan ect i had a huge variety of influences) I heard the song highway to hell and said to myself i want to play that. I picked up my dads acoustic guitar and started playing by ear single string single note. Evolved to chords within a year and studied my blues scales. Learned to solo a couple of years later. That was 1979 and i haven't put down the guitar ever since. No it is not my profession, just a hobby and love of music.

I really think it’s awesome that Travis Barker answered this question, especially since Blink 182 was actually one of the main inspirations I had to learn music. When I was younger, my cousin and I would listen to Blink and then talk about starting our own 3 piece band. My role model was actually Mark Hoppus (the bassist/lower voiced singer in Blink 182), so I was interested in learning bass guitar and singing.I started out learning only the bass, a friend of mine who taught me how to read Tablature, and started getting better at singing later.Not too long after that, I taught myself guitar and got tons of experience singing.Now singing is my absolute favorite thing to do and guitar is 2nd to that. Inspiration is definitely something that keeps coming, in tons of different ways, as you grow as a musician.

I was 14. My dad had a bass lying around, but I don’t remember being all that interested in it. I was more concerned with reading, art, sexual frustration and my favorite new toy, weed. It’s not that I didn’t care for music, I loved the stuff, but the thought that I would be able to actually make music never crossed my mind. Some kids who were a few years older than me had a band and were looking for a bass player. Somehow they had heard about my dad’s bass, and must have figured “bass is easy enough to play, let’s see what happens”, because they asked totally inexperienced me to audition. Of course i didn’t harbor any hopes of passing the audition; I just appreciated the opportunity to hang out with these cool older kids. So my first time playing bass and my first audition coincided. I remember the guitarist explaining how to play Paranoid by Black Sabbath, the drummer counting in the tune and just sort of forgetting everything around me but this amazing noise we were making, completely lost in sound. Mysteriously I ended up passing my audition. I was instantly hooked to playing music, and haven’t stopped since.

Although I studied blues and jazz early on, it was Steely Dan records that got me hooked on "making" music. That people could create something that extraordinary on tape was sublime, and I've been chasing it ever since.

I play guitar since I was 5, and straight up, when I think why I started it was because my older brother had just beginner to play as wellBut after about 2 years he stopped, I continued, he never actually stopped playing, he was always  asking me what I had learned and sometimes even if I could teach him.In my opinion people start playing an instrument because  there's someone in his life that inspires him (my brother) or because music is something that is always around him, that happened to me too, I've loved and listened to music my whole lifeSo the perfect answer to your question would be: what inspires musicians to become what they've become is music itself

When I met Allen, the singer in our band, it was the first time I realized you could do music and be okay. We were in early high school and both basketball players wanting to be in the NBA. But, the more I played music, the more I realized it was something I actually wanted to pursue. It was a slow process and once I got involved in it, it was a puzzle that kept changing. I then realized that making music was a good way to spend my time.

I had an option to go to piano lessons or go swimming when in second grade. we could swim only in the summers on certain days and it was the most awaited moment for all of us.....to just go splash in the pool. My piano teacher though was a strict lady. she sensed that have the kids were dying to be out in the pool rather than in her class. So she gave us an option to go play in the pool or play in her class(piano). Everybody left. I stayed caused i was really frightened of her.But that choice is one of my best ever. Cause i grew older, music became a really important factor in my life. I loved playing the piano. i was getting really good at it. I feel really good to listen to me play... but the real joy is to be able to make somebody else happy with my playing.My buddies, today who chose to go swim, hear me play today, and wish they had stayed back to.My inspiration was.... fear that eventually turned into a love and passion.

I think I may have been as young as five when I heard songs in my head. Not already written songs but ones that I had made up. They sounded so good to me but at the same time frustrating. They were complex and new, but I had no way of writing them down or recording them so the vanished almost as quickly as they came. The strange thing is, it never really bothered me too much because even at a young age I knew there was plenty more where that came from. As soon as I was old enough to pick up a ukulele I was making up songs. New chord? New song. Before I could even play three chords on a real guitar I had a dozen songs. To this day, I'll never understand writers block and if I pick up a guitar or stroke a keyboard an idea of some sort will appear from somewhere. Sometimes I'll ignore it in the time it takes to think it through twice, sometimes I'll commit it to my phone, sometimes I might even write it, record it and master it in the space of a day.I don't know if I will ever call it a gift, but the day I sell my first song then I'll consider it.

I'm not sure if it's an inspiration really, I think it's more of an innate thing. I remember driving with my dad when I was young, probably 2 or 3 and he had Van Halen 1 in the CD player. (I got hit with the good stuff early.) I remember hearing ‘Eruption' and asking, “Dad, what makes that sound?” My dad says, “That's a guitar. The guy playing it is called Eddie Van Halen and he's one of the best.” I remember him telling me that I said I wanted to learn how to do that. Around this same time, I got a little plastic guitar from my grandmother. It never left my side. Then when I hit 12 or 13, I realized I was a horrible excuse for an athlete and decided to immerse myself in music. I guess it had always kind of been there. I just needed my finances to catch up with my ambition.

I started playing piano at an early age around 6 for a few years, then onto violin for a few more years and then my love guitar starting at around 10.  Music is and always was something I will never get bored with.  I have had quite a long journey with it and had varying degrees of success throughout the years, but even now I can spend countless hours creating music, critiquing others' music, and enjoying music of all kinds.  It is something that has stayed with me for over 30 years and I appreciate the inspirational quality it continues to bring.  Music is the one thing that has prevented me from growing old.  I stay young, vibrant and engaged all because of this amazing thing we named music.  I hope you checkout some of the web sites I have developed over the years. http://Page on verycooltunes.comhttp://Page on njsound.comPage on askjohn.comhttp://hotpopular.comPage on bitera.cmhttp://talentlure.comhttp://weRwe.com

When I was a kid, there was a commercial on local TV for the New York City Transit Museum, accompanied by thirty seconds of Billy Strayhorn's "Take The A Train," probably the Ellington orchestra recording from the Blanton-Webster era. I had no idea what it was or who it was by or what it meant or whether it was something I could get involved with (I didn't even know what jazz was) but I knew I was hearing something important. I got the same feeling on those rare occasions when I bumped into an Ellington tune at random. I felt similarly strongly about Michael Jackson, the Beatles, Run-DMC, Howlin' Wolf, the Grateful Dead, and many other people. Still do.

I've always had a strong inclination towards music and I suppose the inspiration to become a musician manifested in one memorable moment when I was listening to classical music with my dad when I was 6. I was in love with the beauty and rapidity of the notes I heard on the radio. The sounds were sweeping, dramatic, and complex. They affected me. So that, and an internal desire to maintain harmony in my mind, constantly inspires me to keep creating and playing music.

I was inspired by Sherlock Holmes to start playing the violin when I was 7 years old (I'm 16 now). I was in the car with my grandparents and I said "All my life, I've always wanted to play the violin."  A few years later, I picked up the trombone and found it super exciting. My middle school band director thought I would like low brass, and she was right. The next year, I taught myself baritone horn, and then later in my seventh grade year I taught myself tuba. I have just stuck with music, and now I participate in the all-state festival on trombone. It's really beautiful, and I hope that I can keep my passion alive as I grow older. I hope you do too! I hope I answered your question!Tomek

I am not sure if it was an inspiration. I was fifteen, on a trip to Croatia, getting bored by the sea, listening to some of my favourite soundtrack music, thinking on one girl I had a crush on. And I thought: “Hey, I could try to write something for her.” I had a guitar by my side. So I made a short and simple stupid love song. Yeah. “Wow, its so damn easy to make music.” Nevertheless, when I got back home, I got myself a few notation scoring software programs and got amazed how good at it I was. I really enjoyed it and the way I could interact with it. Skip ten years into the future. I am now finishing college. In my city, the majority of musicians (amateurs or university teachers) know about a guy who composed his first opera in age sixteen and who wrote another two, of which one was played in 2015. Yeah, myself. I enjoyed the fame in my teens, yet currently I find it weird that people I didnt even know before recognize me and infact know something about me, because they just heard about me from the radio or read about me in the news. Small city.

When I was a kid my parents forced me and my brother to go to church every Sunday. I really disliked going to church.  I was 7 years old and didn't really understand why I was there or what the people were saying.  What I do remember were the folk singers and guitar players who would play music for the service. To me they seemed to be having a great time. So at 7 years old I sat in church and silently said to myself "God, I wish I was a guitar player".

I loved playing drums as a child, but had stopped, than I saw Eddie van Halen doing the two handed technique on electric guitar on tv, bought Steve vai and malmsteen CDs, and never stopped shredding….before I got an electric, I had to endure that nasty steel stringed acoustic, hated the feel and sound, thankfully it was borrowed, but played till my folks felt I was good enough for an electric, now I play shred metal 99% and flamenco nylons a little less than 1%……i m all about the shred, no strumming

Becoming a musician is not a inspiration it is the passion which is present inside the people . The inspiration doesn't help anyone to became a musician,filmmaker,IAS or anything the people who are on this post are not because of inspiration they are here because of their passion and hardworking.None can song well like musician because of inspiration it fully dependent on his/ her hardworking.Inspiration only motivate us to do something . So I want to tell you that become hardworking not depend upon the luck or inspiration which help you to became anything .Be hardworking. Thanks for reading.

I'd had so much fun listening to music that I figured I would have even more fun playing it. I was basically a superfan. Punk rock and its descendants emboldened me to pick up the drums. It was simple, you could hear how it went without somebody explaining it. I soon got some lessons, more gear, branched out into keyboards, vocals, guitar, and into other styles of music as well.

I became a musician after hearing Ivan Lins’ album Juntos (which belonged to my mom). After that, it was the obligatory Beatles who sparked the beginning. After hearing Ivan Lins, I picked up the keyboard. Then I saw the Human League and their video for “Fascination”, and after that, I picked up the guitar just from hearing Jo Callis playing that Les Paul on the vid. It’s been a road that, I’m happy to say, I haven’t left.

An inspiration can by anyone. It can be parent, a friend, your favorite music icon, or a street player. For me, it was one of my friend. Till my college life started, i never thought of playing an instrument, specially guitar. In college i got a room mate who used to play guitar whole day long. which I initially disliked. But after sometime i developed a liking for what he played. I started listening more and more songs. And one crazy day, I picked up guitar to learn my favorite melodies . Now , I like investing more and more time with my instruments.

For me it was my DAD who always secretly cherished to be a musician but never could become the one. He was into administration but his heart belonged to music! Never a trained one but possessed musicianship skill which could make people envious.  I was more into academics and was busy managing my corporate job after my MBA. I still don't know whether it was my gene or destiny or me simply being a lazy bum (:D) which ultimately 'compelled' me to quit my high flying job and settled for an uncertain career.  Before that I had to study extensively in the conservatory and the study is still on. Pursuing 'Music' is a serious business and it's no less cerebral than being a doctor, engineer or a manager. Being an Indian, I just wish someday this social 'stigma' of being a musician fades away and people start respecting our profession. We get paid for making people entertained and trust me it's not an easy job to live with!

I heard a schoolteacher play the violin to my class at age six, and was blown away. No idea why, but my professional career as a violinist has lasted forty years, resulting from that one point. My mum asked me once what I’d like to be when I grew up. I answered ”I want to be a musician!” She replied; “you can’t do both.” How right she was.

We all have different DNA, we are all "programmed" differently. In my humble opinion, if G-d did not want so many things done here on Planet Earth, He would not have created so many people! Some of us are inclined and have a natural talent in music, some in art, some in writing, some in science, etc. The list goes on and on. I would like to just add that it is part nature and part nurture.

two things: they have passion in what they do, and they want to send a message to people who will hear their music, for me i'm still working on the process of finding my sound as a musician, but the one fact about musician is that they are personal about what they do, they write what no one should know about in their lives, and in indirect way people are touch by their music because it's real, and that's how the musician achieves his/her goal of being able to touch others and send an effective message.
I made the decision in 5th grade. Kids in concert band got to skip class for 45 minutes twice a week. School bore me, so I joined band just to skip class. Horrible reason, I know.

For me it was hearing the score for Star Wars. I wanted to be able to do that. Since then I have played the drums for 38 years, composed and arranged music for 30, and been a music teacher for 20. All because of Star Wars!!!

Good morning or good night, depends on where you read this: My personal experience for becoming a musician was to express myself through music. I needed and I wanted to ''vent'' or just let my emotions go through my drumming. Music, as art, is one of many ways to express yourself without any rules or limitations. Been on the scene for ten years now.

My reason was pretty simple. I liked music so much that I decided I wanted to make my own. Same reason people become chefs, artists, librarians, actors, doctors, etc. If any field interests you to the point of obsession, that’s your passion. Go with it.
One does not become a musician, but rather realizes he is one.

Seeing another musician perform live and saying to myself that I want to be able to do what that person is doing which was turning on the crowd and working them into such a frenzy and it was an incredible feeling that I wanted to be THAT guy that turned on THAT crowd and then inspired THAT guy to continue the cycle...

What inspires me as a musician is the ability to channel my emotions through my music and to able to use music as a form of communication and bonding between people . Also knowing that I am making a difference one note at a time, whether it is teaching a new instrument or sharing new creations and compositions.
Two things: 1.  Who Can it Be Now?  By Men at Work.  Loved the saxophone riff. 2.  My saxophone teacher at the time telling me not to.  I am somewhat obstinant and persistent.

I'd say it was because I lived in the country with no friends so music filled the hole but My grandmother was a music teacher and my family were all musician's so that door was open for me. I was going to be a musician one way or the other. A grand piano was my baby sitter.
Frankly, it was not my choice, my parents decided to teach me guitar and music. (I was 6 years old) :D
